headline: Welcome to Bain
pros: Welcome to Bain.  I'm going to give you a problem that neither the CEO nor his entire management team could solve.  And I'm probably going to give you lots of different opinions and imperfect data sources.  And then I'll ask you to focus in on where the most value is and convince all those people with different opinions that you're right.  But don't worry, I'm also going to give you a Bain team.  Those associates and consultants are going to be tenacious in coming up with creative approaches.  Those managers and partners are going to knock down barriers for you, connect you where you need to be connected, guide, support, direct and re-direct you.  The office support staff is going to fix your computer after you spilled coffee on it for the third time, find you the unfindable data source, and smile and hand you a baked good after you ask for help re-doing dozens of slides.  You are empowered and accountable but you are not alone.  And the best part is you can't fail.  Because after all, what all those people are reinforcing is that a Bainie never lets another Bainie fail.
cons: Here's how you know you've made it at Bain.  The reward for doing a good job is getting a bigger, tougher problem next time.  Meaning, you are always solving the easiest problem you will ever solve again.  This takes a lot of resilience and active managing of self-expectations to remember that you are not actually getting worse, the problems are just getting harder.  So my advice is to remember that.  And then take a second to realize that it would be a lot less fun if the reverse were true.  And isn't that precisely why you wanted this job in the first place anyway? It sure was for me.

headline: Only good things to say

headline: Best place to start a career
pros: You'll learn more here than just about anywhere else. The people are tremendous, and Bain has a rock solid culture of fun and respect that I haven't seen at other consulting firms. Your start class will give you friends for life, your managers will become your greatest cheerleaders, and if you choose to leave, the world will be your oyster.
cons: Look, it's tough work. The hours are long, sometimes the job is uninteresting, sometimes clients are a nightmare, sometimes partners are a nightmare, and sometimes your team is a nightmare. That's life. There are other places that will pay you more, work you less, or be more interesting, but if you're looking for a well-rounded job that optimizes for all of the above factors, Bain is probably your best bet.

headline: Company pretends to care about you

cons: The leadership loves saying how much they care about people, the welfare and mental health of employees, etc... and naive people like me usually believe that... until they actually need help/assistance with something regarding their personal lives. HR will tell you that they can't do anything because of "company rules". Partners will tell you the same. Colleagues will feel bad for you but cannot really do anything. In the end, you're just a number and there are thousands of other people dying to work for the company, so your particular issue is not worth their time. You work late nights, weekends, sacrifice your personal life for the job... but when you need something, you're on your own.

headline: Bro Culture, Micromanaging, and Poor Pandemic Response
pros: The benefits are pretty good.
cons:
I feel like this place did a 180 on me. My experience has not matched what was pitched in the interview.  I don't think anyone here is trying to be toxic but they certainly exhibit these behaviors in my experience.  Since starting here I have personally experienced gaslighting, micromanaging (wanting to read your emails for example), being interrupted, having my expertise questioned, etc. I do not feel heard and I do not feel like I have the autonomy needed to do my job. Unfortunately, this is a common experience for those in my demographic.

There are other cultural things that make me uncomfortable as well. There is so much pressure to participate in extracurricular Bain activities e.g. Bain band, pub crawls, etc. that I don't feel like I have a choice in saying no. If that's you're passion, by all means, jump in and have fun; but that's just not for me. The idea of singing songs about my workplace (as they do in Bain Band) is 100% offputting to me. We work here, this is not a capitalist worship house. It's also not super-inclusive to encourage constant after-hours activities (which are often at a bar). Imagine what that would feel like if you had a family, cared for a parent, or didn't drink for one reason or another. I'm not saying I'm against all work events or drinking at these things, I just think they could be more mindful of how this can make others feel. I personally feel obligated to attend lest I want to limit my professional goals. 

They also do these really bizarre reply alls -- to the entire office-- that are at best a waste of people's time and at worse inappropriate. I'm sure I must sound like a killjoy at this point but dang...I just think that folks should be able to opt into how social they want to be with people. I don't need to know about everyone's business to do my job. Don't get me wrong there are a lot of awesome people here and I think it's great to make friends at work. I just think it should be more organic. I don't want to have to comb through 100 emails har-haring at something that I'm not even involved with just to get to my actual work emails.

They've also had a really bizarre approach to the pandemic in recent months. Lately, there has been a huge push to get folks back to the office. Sure there are precautions they have in place, like twice-weekly testing, but it's still an odd choice to pack folks into the open floor plan (most people maskless to boot) just for the sake of it. What's really odd is how jovial they seem to be about it. They'll email out pictures of crowded lunchrooms, meetings, etc as evidence of how great it is that folks are back and then offhandedly mention the breakthrough cases that happened. I get that there is a value in being in the same space every now and again but to what end? We can't simply will the pandemic to end and folks are working perfectly well from home. It just comes off as that old-school management thing where they want to watch over your shoulder all the time.


There are also a lot of issues with the values and historical decks/content that would 100% not fly today(but are still being used for some reason). For example, they want you to have an "insurgent mindset" which is just really gross sounding. A lot of what they do feel like 1984 doublespeak to me. For example, a few women on a recent panel talked about how great Bain was to them when they became mothers. They both mentioned stepping into lower roles so they could be with their kids more. Now on the one hand this could be a great thing...if Bain is helping people with kids find the right work-life balance then that's cool. Unfortunately, I didn't get that vibe. I might be reading into it too much but their stories made it sound like leadership roles at Bain require so much work after hours that it'd be very difficult for parents (especially mothers ) to maintain them. I'm not saying this is the case, this is simply my impression of what was shared. 

Overall I just think this place is designed for people with very different backgrounds than my own.

headline: Best place to work!

pros:
Bain is a company that not only talks about its culture but is a company that the culture is lived and breathed every day from all levels of the organization. From the moment you walk into the office on your first day, you feel welcome, appreciated, and respected. I have been with Bain for a year and during this year I have had the opportunity to work with a number of different people in varying roles; From my direct boss to her boss, I feel as though I have support when I need it and mentors to look up to. The caliber of the individuals at Bain is very high and you are always challenged to do your best, which is ideal when you want to thrive and grow with a company. From our office head down, I feel as though the support and care are genuine.
Bain is able to make coming to work fun! There are so many social events that you can get involved in, which also foster interconnectivity between different departments/people.
Bain has handled COVID in a way that has been supportive to the employees by allowing budgets for home ergonomics and technology to optimize the WFH set up. Although many things are unknown for the world right now, I feel as though Bain has been communicative throughout the whole process.
This is a company that I love and am very proud to work at! Bain is forward-thinking, inclusive, proactive, and ahead of the curve in many respects. This is the kind of company that you aspire to work for.
cons: No cons to report at this time as all questions and queries I have are usually always resolved.

headline: Great Company, but be comfortable with your offer
pros:
Bain has an incredible working community. There truly aren't weak links in this chain, I've never worked in a place where I am so appreciate and supported by my co-workers. It's generally very invested in it's employees and the benefits are very thoughtful. 

There are a lot of places to plug in, but you really have to be motivated and self-starting in order to go anywhere here. In the assistant position, potential growth is extremely limited and there is not currently a path for assistants to be promoted within the company.
cons:
There is zero wage transparency and many antiquated compensation practices that negatively impact BIPOC and women for hourly employees. 

If you're expecting salary growth, this is not the company for you. There is one promotion available to assistants with a significant raise and after that you're done. This promotion is based more on the needs of the company than the qualifications of the employees, so you could be waiting for less than a year for a promotion, or you could be there for 4 years. 

Raises are typically awarded at about the rate of inflation and are non-negotiable. If you are comfortable with your salary offer, you'll be fine.

Manager Assistants support six people and are not allowed overtime. It's a response to the pandemic that they are currently planning on making permanent. Do not factor in overtime to your compensation because they expect you to keep your hours under 40 a week (and it's not a 40-hour a week job, closer to 45-50 if you're working at a sustainable pace).

headline: Great foundation for career progression surrounded by passionate colleagues
pros:
The people at Bain are truly top notch. It's incredible to feel like you're a part of a community that's in your corner and wants to propel your career, no matter where it may head. The amount that you can learn from the work, the people, the clients, etc. is incredible. The people at Bain truly believe in their culture and work can sometimes be, dare I say it, fun because of the energy everyone brings to the table!

The amount of exposure you get to see how Fortune 500 companies operate is incredible. 

Benefits are top notch, 5% 401k contribution, despite what you put in (better than matching!)

Company is very transparent about the state of the business.

Fast career trajectory.
cons:
Work life balance is challenging broadly in the management consulting field, however Bain does a relatively good job relative to its peers, with a "GAL" (get-a-life) / "virtual baby" culture where you get ~1 early night per week, typically. Work hours can range from ~55-80 hours per week depending on the client, office, and manager. 

Staffing is a bit of a challenge in that you don't necessarily know where you'll be on the next case - either in terms of work life balance, or physical location - and you only get some say in the matter.

headline: Amazing and rewarding place to learn and grow; best company culture I've encountered hands down

-Extremely rewarding at each stage of the career from a compensation and benefits perspective
-High touch professional development team helps you feel like you're not just a cog-in-the-wheel, I feel like I've had a very personalized journey through Bain over 6 years
-Best culture and combination of high performance people that actually treat each other well
-I feel prepared to go do so many different things, and at the same time I've continually opted into the role and the path here
cons:
The two things the firm is working to address are consistent with what I would observe:
-Sustainability - this is a hard job. A really hard job. The culture is super high performing and the problems we solve are not easy. This means that it's hard to turn your brain off of the work even if you leave for home at a reasonable hour. The upside is that relative to other consulting firms, the home office staffing model does very materially make this more of a sustainable place to build a long-term career in consulting. I've been here 6 years and could not have possibly done that if traveling 4 days/week as at many other firms. 
-Diversity and inclusion - consistent with many aspects of the corporate world, Bain is behind where it wants to / needs to be on the dimension of consulting staff diversity. I've been encouraged by how

headline: People come first. Period.
pros:
- Incredible team of people. Lots of companies say they put their people first, but Bain actually does it. Let's acknowledge upfront that that makes a lot of business sense in a world where people are the product, but Bain truly delivers. Some examples: I had a team who fought for me, who pushed against the odds and the statistics, to get me the opportunities that were exciting to me. I had someone who worked for me who dropped everything when her peer's father caught COVID - this led to some crazy hours and stressful days, but this individual believed in our operating principle "A Bainie Never Lets Another Bainie Fail" - something that has permeated everyday of my career here. My path hasn't been standard but I have felt deeply supported and seen as an individual at each step of the way. 
- We do great work for our clients. Cliche, I know. But as I work with my clients, it's clear that Bain is different. We focus on delivering value that the client can actually realize - it's not about the academically perfect answer or something complex that will require 5 more years of consulting. It's about making the client successful. 
- Can't get thru 2020 without mentioning COVID. Bain went work from home before SF city ordinances (which were some of the earliest in the country) and has put employee safety first at every step. This includes people moving across the country to be with family or needing flexible work schedules to manage child care or other WFH needs.
- We aren't the most diverse company and have struggled to recruit and retain people of color and LGBTQ individuals. And I've seen Bain step up this year to fix this. Including massive financial commitments, changes to our operating principles, Diversity committee to report to MD to evaluate and track stats, an Americas-wide Juneteenth training on systemic racism and what it means at Bain. We are nowhere near the end of the road here, but as a gay woman, I believe in what the leadership is saying and setting out as a goal and direction for the company.
cons:
- it can be a bit of "you put in X years, you get Y reward" but I do think that's shifting over time
- If you aren't starting as an AC (right out of college) ... it can be alienating - the ACs who work here get such incredible opportunities and boosts that those joining out of biz school never had... I've heard many people discount how hard it is to get into schools like HBS and GSB because "it's just expected." As someone who fought for that degree, it can come off as cavalier, discounting, and perhaps "holier than thou" (oh you had to work for this thing that was just a duh for me? poor you...). Have to develop a tough skin and know that your path was worthy and real and important to survive that egotistical stuff.

When push comes to shove (when you attempt to be "at cause"), and they have to "deal with you," they will make you feel like YOU are the problem.  This is also because they lack the skill-set to effectively mediate a situation.  Do not try to voice a concern, this will only make YOU look "difficult."  

Basically, they are about themselves, not you.  If you have a problem, they will turn it against you and then have HR gang up on you to make you feel like even less of a person.  I've seen this happen with almost every person I've ever worked with in Graphics for the last 10 years, and it's getting worse by the year.  If you don't mind being a grunt without a voice, this is the place for you.  I didn't often seen happy faces walking down those newly designed halls.. most people seem miserable and unfriendly.

headline: Best place to jumpstart your career
pros:
I started with Bain out of school and have stayed longer than I ever thought I would.  What I love about the job is the combination of...
- Accelerated learning (chance to manage teams very early in your career)
- Working on hot topics (cases working on C-level issues)
- The commitment to people (weekly coaching, consistent sponsorship) 
- The flexibility to make the job work for me (externships, LOAs, part-time)
- Feeling financially rewarded (pay off student debt fast, feel very secure)
cons: My biggest challenge in working at Bain is travel and 'having it all' (the client I want, the team I want, but all of that local to me).  There are ways to minimize time away from home - like working with private equity or local clients - but I haven't historically prioritized those in my planning, which means more time on planes and less time to be with friends during the week.

The people -- they are without a doubt the smartest, hardest working people I know but yet still know how to have fun and build a collaborative team environment

The company -- this company does so many things right; they have a very clear rubric for what is expected of you at every different role, and you can see how your role will grow and change over time. They also do a great job of giving reviews, both formal and informal to ensure that you are growing and developing over time. They also build in a lot of time to build the culture and develop a workplace that makes people want to show up.
cons: You don't have complete control over the projects that you work on, so you may end up doing something that you don't like. The work and the hours can be very difficult and can be unsustainable in the long run.

headline: Clearly the best place to work!!!
pros:
Bain allows people the flexibility to tailor their careers to their own interests and passions.  By ‘building your own Bain’, our team is able to test out different industries, different management topics, and different geographies throughout their time at Bain.  This allows them the ability to learn what gives them energy on the job, and shape their future career and experiences accordingly.

In addition to this, Bain supports all of its team as we build our own Bain through its apprenticeship model.  You are constantly challenged not the job as the clients, topics, and teams you work with are constantly changing, and expectations for your role increase as well.  But you always have more than enough support from mentors, sponsors, coaches, and supervisors to help ensure you that your ramp up quickly and are able to meet those challenges.  Truly, this apprenticeship focus is the best part of Bain & Company, and one that has helped me develop rapidly throughout my career here.

headline: Best In Class
pros:
Best in class client results - I hear over and over again from my clients that "it just feels different to team with Bainies." They love our work, and they also love working with us. That makes a client services job incredibly rewarding as you often find yourself developing strong friendships, as well as advisory relationships, with senior clients. Our rate of enduring clients who actively call Bain for their toughest problems speaks for itself. 

Strong supportive culture - It's in the DNA of Bainies to support one another, coach, and mentor. I feel like I have an amazing set of mentors supporting my career, all the way from Senior Directors to my peers to our ACs. 

No better place to start your career - I am in awe at the opportunities Bain creates for our ACs and Cs to develop the general manager mindset. We constantly push our teams to deliver the best work we can, and as part of this we stretch our people to learn new skills and build towards their personal career goals. It is awesome to watch Bainies succeed, both at Bain and outside of Bain.
cons: Client services is inherently demanding and at times unpredictable. However, Bain really does support you in finding a balance that works for you. Increasingly you have control over your schedule and I've found that helps provide mental wellness all in, carving out enough time for my own life outside of work, and flexing work hours as needed to do that.

headline: Unparalleled culture and opportunity - lives up to the hype
pros:
-The breadth and quality of the cases you can cover are hard to come by in all but a few other consulting firms
-The office based staffing model makes Bain more sustainable than other firms; I interned with another consulting firm where I traveled 4 days a week and was only in my home office on Fridays. I found it unsustainable and felt I didn't know the people in my own office. At Bain, when you don't have client meetings, you can be in your local office. This means you have a more reasonable travel schedule and you really get to know your colleagues. 
-Compensation and benefits are great - can't complain, comparable to similar employers
-Bain is serious about your development. It's viewed as an apprencticeship and your team really invests in your professional development, regular check-ins to talk about what you're doing well and how you can do better.
-If you work here, within a matter of months you will start getting multiple solicitations to go work for another company at a level that would be hard to crack into a few years out of business school; I've been recruited almost more heavily here at Bain than when I was in business school.
cons:
-The nature of client service is that you'll have an unpredictable schedule. I've averaged 60 hours a week but it's felt managable so far. If you rotate into the Private Equity Group you won't travel at all but you'll expect to work longer hours due to the nature of the work.
-Yeah, the only down side is the work life balance - this is not and will never be a 9-to-5 job, but you probably know that already.
